JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Elisabeth Steiner;Erik Møse;Khanlar Hajiyev;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Peer Lorenzen
TEXT: The applicants are Mr PERSON Aloyan , who is a NORP national born in DATE , and PERSON , who is an NORP national born in DATE . The applicants live in GPE . They were represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG were represented by PERSON , a former Representative of GPE at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicants’ son , Mr PERSON , born in DATE , left his apartment in GPE , drove away and was not seen again .

On DATE officers from GPE no . CARDINAL police station found the applicant ’s son ’s car in a car park in GPE . According to the Government , the officers then unlawfully used the car from that date until DATE , when PERSON relatives found and identified the car as belonging to him .
On DATE the burned remains of a man with a gunshot entry wound to the back of the head were found in GPE in the GPE region .

On DATE a medical forensic examination was carried out on the remains in the context of criminal proceedings opened on DATE ( see below ) . The experts stated that the death could have been caused by a gunshot wound to the head . Also , a ring made from yellow metal with a white metal setting with CARDINAL rows of white precious stones was found on the little finger of the right hand of the body . A fragment of a black shoe with a leather sole was found on the left foot , a fragment of cotton fabric of a yellow - brown colour , a fragment from a grey sweater and a crucifix made of white metal were found on the neck and chest of the body .

During a witness interview of DATE , CARDINAL of PERSON brothers , PERSON , stated that his missing brother had been wearing a gold ring with white diamonds on the little finger of his right hand . DATE he identified the ring and the fragments of clothes and shoe which had been on the dead body found on CARDINAL DATE as belonging to his brother , PERSON . The body was then handed over to the applicants , who buried it in GPE .

On DATE CARDINAL sets of criminal proceedings were instituted , in connection respectively with the disappearance of the applicants’ son and the discovery of the dead body in GPE . The cases were later joined under the number CARDINAL ; the investigation was carried out under LAW ( premeditated murder ) of FAC then in force .

It appears that the applicants retained doubts as to the identity of the body found in GPE on CARDINAL DATE . In DATE they met a certain Mr S. , who , according to him , had been held in division no . CARDINAL of psychiatric hospital no . CARDINAL in the town of PERSON in LOC ( “ the PERSON psychiatric hospital ” ) and had seen the applicants’ son there in DATE . The applicants insisted that PERSON could have been abducted by officers of police station no . CARDINAL of GPE , or by officers of the GPE Region department of the fight against organised crime , who had carried out a special operation in FAC casino in GPE on DATE . In this latter respect , the applicant alleged that on the date of his disappearance their son had telephoned them on his mobile phone and stated that he was in that casino . The applicants also insisted that officers of the NORP town prosecutor ’s office , acting with medical experts , showed them their son ’s personal belongings for identification – a ring and a crucifix – and then delivered to them another man ’s body which had been burned to an extent which made identification impossible . The applicants further claimed that after he was abducted their son had been placed in the PERSON psychiatric hospital .

According to the Government , the investigating authorities thoroughly checked all aspects of the version put forward by the applicants and did not find any evidence to support it . The applicants on their part had been highly uncooperative and had obstructed the course of the investigation by numerous refusals to take part in investigative actions . In support of their submissions , the Government referred to the documents from the criminal investigation file in case no . DATE . These documents reveal the following .
On DATE the body found in LOC on DATE was examined by medical experts ( see above ) .
On DATE Mr PERSON identified the remains as those of his brother , PERSON ( see above ) .

According to an expert report of DATE , pieces of fabric collected during the inspection of the scene where the corpse was found , represented a piece of a sweater of a blue - grey colour and a piece of cotton denim fabric .
During their interviews , witnesses who had seen PERSON on DATE of his disappearance stated that he had been wearing a blue - grey sweater and jeans .

In a witness interview of DATE , Mr PERSON , CARDINAL of ORG brothers , stated that he had no doubts that the body found on CARDINAL DATE in LOC was that of PERSON . He added that he had been in conflict with his parents , the applicants , after PERSON death , because they insisted that the latter was alive . Mr PERSON also stated that he could not explain why his parents believed his deceased brother was alive .

DATE and CARDINAL DATE a medical forensic molecular - genetic ( DNA ) examination of the remains found in GPE was carried out on the basis of blood samples provided by PERSON , CARDINAL of ORG brothers . It was thus confirmed that the remains were those of PERSON .

In a witness interview of DATE Mr S. , born in DATE , stated that DATE and DATE he had undergone treatment in the PERSON psychiatric hospital . According to him , from DATE of his admission to hospital until DATE he had been held in division no . CARDINAL of that hospital , and afterwards he had been transferred to another division . Mr S. further stated that in DATE his wife , who had come to see him in hospital , had shown him a newspaper article with PERSON photograph stating that his parents were looking for him and that he had been abducted by the police and placed in the PERSON psychiatric hospital . In Mr S. ’s submission , having looked at the photograph , he had recognised PERSON , as he had seen the latter in division no . CARDINAL during DATE Mr S. said he had spent there .

According to a report of DATE on PERSON psychiatric forensic examination , at the relevant time the latter had been suffering from a mental disorder of a kind which made him mentally incompetent and incapable of adequately perceiving and understanding reality . Moreover , PERSON mental state at present made it impossible for him to participate in the investigation . The investigation also established that PERSON had spent DATE in division no . CARDINAL of the PERSON psychiatric hospital rather than DATE as had been alleged by him . Moreover , only elderly patients were admitted to that division , therefore under no circumstances could a person of PERSON age be held there .

The materials of the criminal investigation file further reveal that enquiries had been made of the PERSON psychiatric hospital by various authorities , including ORG , and that medical personnel were questioned in the course of the investigation ; however , no evidence that PERSON had ever been in that hospital was ever obtained .

It is clear from the submitted materials that a number of other investigative actions were also taken . In particular , a number of expert examinations of various kinds were conducted , with a view to establishing the time and cause of PERSON death , and numerous witnesses were interviewed . Some witnesses indicated by the applicants as those who had certain information concerning their son had been questioned on several occasions , and confrontations between them and the applicants were held . All the witnesses were consistent in their statements and denied having any meaningful information concerning PERSON , or having given the applicants any information concerning his fate , as the latter alleged .

In particular , as regards the applicants’ version of events , that their son had been abducted by police during a special operation in FAC casino on CARDINAL DATE , several witnesses who had been in the casino on DATE , including CARDINAL of ORG brothers , denied having seen PERSON there at any time on the date in question . Also , a number of witnesses were interviewed in connection with the applicants’ version that their son had been abducted by officers from police station no . CARDINAL who had then used his car . It was established that the officers in question had found PERSON car abandoned in a car park and used it , in breach of their duties , instead of reporting the finding of an unidentified car to their superiors ; however , no evidence of their involvement in ORG abduction and/or murder had ever been found .

The materials of the investigation file in case no . DATE also contain numerous reports by the investigators in charge of the case at various times , indicating that throughout the investigation the applicants had repeatedly refused to take part in it , and in particular to participate in witness interviews and confrontations , to submit the remains found on CARDINAL DATE and the items found along with the remains for additional expert examinations , to provide blood samples for DNA analysis of the remains , and so on .

A decision of DATE , by which the criminal proceedings in case no . DATE were terminated on the latest occasion for failure to establish the identities of those responsible , stated , inter alia , that in their complaints against the investigating authorities the applicants had mainly alleged that those authorities were biased and had not been diligent in carrying out the investigation . According to the decision , the applicants had proposed various versions as regards the involvement of various people in abducting their son and putting him in the PERSON psychiatric hospital , and had insisted that those people had information concerning their son ’s whereabouts . The decision went on to say that , once all those versions had been thoroughly checked , by , inter alia , confrontations between the applicants and the individuals to whom they had referred , and had been rejected , the applicants would accuse the investigating authorities of incompetence and bias and would advance other versions , which , in their turn , would prove to be unfounded . The decision also stated that in the course of the investigation the authorities had investigated versions according to which PERSON might have been killed as a member of a criminal group in a territorial struggle with other criminal groups .

On DATE the first applicant lodged with ORG , GPE ( “ the ORG ” ) a complaint against the head of the PERSON psychiatric hospital . The first applicant alleged that he had information that his son , PERSON , was being unlawfully kept in that hospital . He further complained that the hospital authorities had consistently refused to provide him with information concerning his son ’s state of health and location , and requested the court to order that he be provided with the information .

On DATE ORG dismissed the first applicant ’s complaint with reference to the absence of any evidence that PERSON had ever been held in the PERSON psychiatric hospital . It had rejected as unreliable the testimony given by PERSON , who had been summoned and examined by the court at the first applicant ’s request , to the effect that he had seen PERSON in the PERSON psychiatric hospital . The court referred to the results of the enquiries made of the hospital by various authorities , and to the list of patients admitted to the hospital in DATE which did not include PERSON name . It appears that during the proceedings the first applicant requested ORG to call and examine some other witnesses on his behalf , however failed to indicate their full names and addresses , as was required by domestic law then in force .
On DATE ORG upheld the above judgment on appeal .
